pages.text: With masonry bricks, several machines open up to you: The $(item)Stone Sawmill, Oven, Kiln, and Crucible/$.$(p)The Stone Kiln is required for $(item)glass/$, while also having a higher success rate and faster speed than the pit kiln.$(p)The sawmill is required for $(item)boards/$, and the crucible is required for $(item)liquid clay/$.

Each of these needs fuel inserted into the bottom, which is ignited with a fire-starting item like $(item)flint and tinder/$ or a $(item)bow drill/$.$(p)Another very important thing to build is a $(thing)pit burning setup/$, not to be confused with the pit kiln. See the next page for construction.

pages.name: Pit Burning
pages.text: 2x2x2 example. Can be any size up to 27 interior blocks.

Fill the entire structure with valid blocks (like $(item)log piles/$), then light one of the inner blocks on fire and close the door. The structure $(bold)must/$ be filled, or it will fail. Right click the faucet to extract fluids into a tank.$(br)$(br)$(li)4 Stone Collectors$(li)1 Stone Drain$(li)1 Stone Faucet$(li)1 Stone Tank$(li)1 Stone Door$(li)Some $(thing)non-flammable/$ blocks, like dirt.

The two recipes of interest for pit burning involve $(item)log piles/$ and $(item)mud blocks/$.$(p)Log piles will give $(item)charcoal and wood tar/$, and mud blocks will give $(item)clay blocks and water/$.$(p)Only fill it with one block type at a time. Harvest the result with a shovel.
